description: Build and execute command lines from standard input

tasks.title: Basic xargs Usage
tasks.description: Use echo to output 'file1.txt file2.txt' and pipe to xargs to remove them with rm.
hints: xargs reads from stdin and passes as arguments
Default behavior splits on whitespace
Each word becomes a separate argument
tasks.explanation: xargs reads whitespace-separated items from stdin and passes them as arguments to the specified command.

tasks.title: xargs with find
tasks.description: Find all .tmp files in the current directory and delete them using xargs rm.
hints: find outputs filenames, xargs passes them to rm
Common pattern: find | xargs command
More efficient than find -exec for many files
tasks.explanation: This common pattern uses find to locate files and xargs to execute commands on them efficiently.

tasks.title: xargs with Null Delimiter
tasks.description: Find all .txt files using null terminators, and pass them to 'ls -l' using xargs with the null delimiter option.
hints: Use -print0 with find for null-terminated output
Use -0 with xargs to read null-delimited input
Handles filenames with spaces safely
tasks.explanation: The -0 option makes xargs use null characters as delimiters, safely handling filenames with spaces.

tasks.title: Limit Arguments per Command
tasks.description: List files with ls and use xargs to echo them in batches of 5.
hints: Use -n followed by number
Limits how many arguments per command execution
Useful for commands with argument limits
tasks.explanation: The -n option limits the number of arguments passed to each command execution, processing in batches.

tasks.title: Interactive Mode
tasks.description: List *.txt files and use xargs to remove them, prompting for confirmation before each execution with -p.
hints: Use -p for prompt mode
Asks for confirmation before each execution
Useful for dangerous operations
tasks.explanation: The -p option prompts for confirmation before executing each command, providing safety for destructive operations.

tasks.title: Replace String with Arguments
tasks.description: List *.txt files and use xargs with a placeholder '{}' to copy each file to a .bak extension.
hints: Use -I followed by replacement string (commonly {})
The string is replaced with each input item
Allows complex command construction
tasks.explanation: The -I option specifies a replacement string that gets substituted with each input item, enabling complex commands.

tasks.title: Parallel Execution
tasks.description: List *.jpg files and process them with 'convert' in parallel using 4 processes, handling 1 file per command.
hints: Use -P followed by number of processes
Runs commands in parallel
Useful for CPU-intensive tasks
tasks.explanation: The -P option enables parallel execution with the specified number of concurrent processes.

tasks.title: Specify Different Command
tasks.description: List *.log files and use xargs to grep for the string "ERROR" in them.
hints: Command comes after xargs options
Arguments from stdin are appended
Default command is 'echo' if none specified
tasks.explanation: The command to execute is specified after xargs options, with stdin arguments appended to it.

tasks.title: Handle Empty Input
tasks.description: Find files named "nonexistent" and pipe to xargs rm, using the option to prevent execution if no input is received.
hints: Use -r to not run if input is empty
Prevents errors when no input provided
Also called --no-run-if-empty
tasks.explanation: The -r option prevents xargs from executing the command when there's no input from stdin.

tasks.title: Set Maximum Line Length
tasks.description: List files and use xargs to echo them, limiting the command line length to 100 characters.
hints: Use -s followed by character limit
Ensures command lines don't exceed system limits
Automatically adjusts number of arguments
tasks.explanation: The -s option sets the maximum command line length, automatically adjusting the number of arguments per execution.

tasks.title: Process Single Item at a Time
tasks.description: List *.txt files and use xargs to run 'wc -l' on each file individually.
hints: Use -n 1 for one argument per execution
Each input item gets processed separately
Useful when command output needs to be separate
tasks.explanation: Using -n 1 processes each input item individually, running the command once per item.

tasks.title: xargs with Environment Variables
tasks.description: Echo "file1 file2" and use xargs with placeholder '{}' to run 'env VAR={} command' for each item.
tasks.command: echo "file1 file2" | xargs -I {} env VAR={} command
hints: Use env command to set variables
Combine with -I for replacement
Each execution gets its own environment
tasks.explanation: You can use the env command with xargs to set environment variables for each command execution.

tasks.title: Show Commands Before Execution
tasks.description: List *.txt files and use xargs to remove them, printing each command to stderr before execution.
hints: Use -t to trace/show commands
Prints each command to stderr before execution
Useful for debugging xargs commands
tasks.explanation: The -t option traces command execution by printing each command to stderr before running it.

tasks.title: Custom Delimiter
tasks.description: Echo "a,b,c" and use xargs to echo the items, using a comma as the custom delimiter.
hints: Use -d followed by delimiter character
Changes from default whitespace splitting
Useful for CSV or custom-formatted input
tasks.explanation: The -d option specifies a custom delimiter character for splitting input instead of whitespace.

tasks.title: Exit on Command Failure
tasks.description: List *.txt files and use xargs with the '-e' option to remove them (exit on failure).
hints: Use -e to exit on first command failure
Stops processing remaining items
Useful when order matters
tasks.explanation: The -e option makes xargs exit immediately if any command execution fails, stopping further processing.

tasks.title: Read from File Instead of Stdin
tasks.description: Use xargs to remove items listed in 'filelist.txt', reading directly from the file.
hints: Use -a followed by filename
Reads input from file instead of stdin
File should contain whitespace-separated items
tasks.explanation: The -a option specifies a file to read input from instead of using standard input.

tasks.title: Combine with Complex Pipeline
tasks.description: Find files larger than 1M, sort them, and use xargs with placeholder '{}' to long-list (ls -lh) each file.
hints: Chain multiple commands with pipes
xargs can be part of longer pipelines
Use -I for complex argument substitution
tasks.explanation: xargs integrates well into complex pipelines, allowing sophisticated data processing workflows.

tasks.title: Handle Special Characters
tasks.description: Find .txt files safely (using -print0) and use xargs (using -0) to echo "Processing: {filename}" for each.
hints: Use -print0 and -0 for null termination
Use -I {} for proper quoting
Handles all special characters safely
tasks.explanation: Combining null termination (-print0/-0) with replacement strings (-I) safely handles filenames with any special characters.

tasks.title: Run Complex Commands with sh
tasks.description: Find *.log files and use xargs with sh -c to run 'echo Processing [file]' followed by 'gzip [file]' for each.
hints: Use sh -c to run a shell string
Combine with -I to insert argument into the shell string
Allows piping and multiple commands per Item
tasks.explanation: Using 'sh -c' allows executing complex command strings involving pipes, redirections, or multiple commands for each argument.

tasks.title: Batch Directory Creation
tasks.description: Echo the paths "src/test src/main docs/api" and use xargs (processing 1 at a time) to create them with mkdir -p.
hints: Pipe list of paths to xargs
Use mkdir -p to create parent directories
-n 1 ensures each path is handled if spaces exist or just to be safe
tasks.explanation: xargs can take a list of paths and pass them to mkdir -p to create complex directory structures efficiently in one go.

tasks.title: Find and Archive
tasks.description: Find *.conf files and use xargs to create a tar archive named 'configs.tar' containing them.
hints: find outputs filenames
xargs passes all filenames as arguments to tar
Much more efficient than running tar for each file
tasks.explanation: xargs passes all found filenames to tar in one command execution (if they fit in command line limit), creating a single archive containing all of them.

tasks.title: Count Lines in Multiple Files
tasks.description: List *.txt files and use xargs to pass them to wc -l.
hints: Use ls *.txt to list the files
Pipe to xargs
wc -l counts lines in files
tasks.explanation: xargs takes the list of filenames from ls and passes them all as arguments to wc -l, which then counts lines in each file.

tasks.title: Parallel File Downloads
tasks.description: Cat 'urls.txt' and use xargs (1 per command, 4 parallel) to download with curl -O.
hints: Use -P 4 to run 4 processes in parallel
Use -n 1 to pass one URL to each curl command
curl -O downloads the file saving it with the remote name
tasks.explanation: Running curl in parallel significantly speeds up downloading multiple files. -P controls concurrency.

tasks.title: Search and Replace in Files
tasks.description: Recursively list files containing "TODO" in the current directory, and use xargs to replace "TODO" with "DONE" in-place using sed.
hints: Use grep -rl to list files containing the string
Pipe to xargs to pass filenames
Use sed -i for in-place replacement
tasks.explanation: This powerful pipeline finds files with content using grep and processes only those files with sed to perform replacements.

tasks.title: Preview Commands with Echo
tasks.description: Find *.tmp files and use xargs to preview the 'rm' command (using echo) without executing it.
hints: Put 'echo' before the command you want to preview
xargs will run echo rm filename...
Allows you to see the arguments before execution
tasks.explanation: Using 'echo' before the command is a great safety habit to verify arguments before running destructive commands.

tasks.title: Rename Files (Extension Change)
tasks.description: Find *.txt files and use xargs with a placeholder to run a shell command converting extensions to .md: sh -c 'mv "$1" "${1%.txt}.md"' _ {}
hints: Use sh -c to execute a shell script for each file
Use parameter expansion ${1%.txt}.md to change extension
Pass {} as argument to sh -c
tasks.explanation: Changing file extensions in batch often requires sh -c to leverage shell parameter expansion features.
